componenttext: John, I'm just going to make some opening comments and then pass it over to Hugh to really address it. First, I'm troubled by the word reduction in guidance. We are saying we tightened the guidance. We gave you a range, 11% to 13%. All that we're doing now is tightening the guidance. So we feel very good about where we've been so far in the year, and we feel good about the fourth quarter. And in today's macroeconomic environment, to deliver 11% to 12% EPS growth for a company of our size and scale, I think it's fantastic performance. So that's the first point. Point two, we're managing the company for the long term. And when we see opportunities to make investments, which we think will pay off may not be in the next quarter or two, but over the long term. Because many of these require investments in platforms in R&D, we are going to make those investments because we have to make sure that we're looking at innovation 24, 36 months out. Because as we move more in more into the nutrition space, it's no longer mere line extensions, but we have to think about products backed by science. And science takes some time to be proved and authenticated and that's what we're focusing on. But that's just a word by way of preamble. Let me turn it over to Hugh to give you a much more detailed answer on this topic. Hugh?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Indra. So John, in terms of tightening the range, first and foremost, we give you a broader range obviously back in the spring of 11% to 13%. We're now tightening it to 11% to 12%, as we've now gotten into Q4 and the latter part of the year, we ob
componenttext: Thanks, Indra. So John, in terms of tightening the range, first and foremost, we give you a broader range obviously back in the spring of 11% to 13%. We're now tightening it to 11% to 12%, as we've now gotten into Q4 and the latter part of the year, we obviously had more line of sight as to where the year is ultimately going to come in. The second point on that is, we're seeing signs that the investments that we have been making in the business really are creating payback, whether you look at things that are going on with an NAB or the things that are happening internationally with China and India and developing markets. So as we see that positive response, we do view it as an opportunity to invest more, and frankly, an opportunity to get good pay back over time. In terms of the specific investments, what we're really doing is investing, I think in a couple of places -- and a lot of it is additional relative to what we've talked about in the past, which is further investments in things like China and Russia, in areas like selling, coolers, rack and systems infrastructure. Second, in brand building, particularly in NAB, around things like MAX and Sierra Mist. And third, as we talked about these Global Nutrition Group, it's making investments in things that will support our future and nutrition, things like Quaker brand building and innovation and investments around fruits and vegetables, salt reduction and grains technology. So these are the types of investments that, as Indra said, are things that are going to pay back over time, but they're the types of investments that really do drive the long-term value of the company. Regarding your question specifically on 2011, we're really not prepared to share guidance on 2011 just yet. We'll do that in the fourth quarter as have been our previous practice.

componenttext: So Bill, we've talked about in the past the $150 million in the context of the overall $0.10 that we're looking to invest in the business this year. And no big change in that other than to some degree in dimension. And what we've talked about in the past are, number one, putting money into brand building into NAB. And it's not an insignificant percentage, but we've also talked about investments in China, investments in India, investments in Russia in order to build out those businesses, which is also getting a pretty good percentage. Beyond that, we really haven't gotten into the specifics for competitive reasons as to where the money is going.

componenttext: The only thing I would add is that, again, I think we feel very good about the quarter in a difficult environment. You've seen the top line and volume improve the last couple of quarters. And if you think about the segments, Water was positive, led by enhanced water. Non-carbs were strong across the board, Tea, Isotonic Energy, ready-to-drink coffee. And the CSD category did experience some softness, but as you mentioned, we feel great. I think MAX is exceeding our expectations. And we actually feel very good about the top line performance across beverages broadly.

componenttext: I think that captures the essence of it. I mean, obviously this is a balance that we're trying to strike. componenttext: I don't want to get hung up on this guidance versus investments here. But just to follow up on the synergy number this year, it is coming in at the high end of the $125 million to $150 million. It sounds like you've got investments that are in addition to what you've laid out as part of the synergy target. So what's driving this year as synergy target increase? And does it give you some comfort around maybe getting more realization over the next three years?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think we've fine tuned our post-merger integration processes a lot, Judy. As we've mentioned to you, we have a very well-tuned process. And so when we -- our start up PMI work, the team's going to action, and when they start executing programs rapi
componenttext: Well I think we've fine tuned our post-merger integration processes a lot, Judy. As we've mentioned to you, we have a very well-tuned process. And so when we -- our start up PMI work, the team's going to action, and when they start executing programs rapidly, you start getting the synergies a little bit earlier. Again, let the year finish. Right now, we're saying it could come in at $150 million. Let the year finish then we'll start talking about what the next year will bring in terms of additional synergies or lack thereof. But it's too early to tell you what next year's going to be. Did you want to add anything, Hugh?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Indra. What I'd add to that, and Judy as we go into those things there's of course two variables we're planning for: Number one is the amount that we'll get out of any initiative; and number two is the timing that well get out of the initiative. I
componenttext: Yes, Indra. What I'd add to that, and Judy as we go into those things there's of course two variables we're planning for: Number one is the amount that we'll get out of any initiative; and number two is the timing that well get out of the initiative. In terms of the amounts, some of them are exceeding, some of them are falling short. The net is, they're coming in about where we would have expected to. The things that we're seeing is we're actually able to get some things done faster than what we had previously planned. So from the standpoint of the three-year number of $400 million, no real change in that. We're really seeing just good opportunities to accelerate timing relative to our original planning.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following up on North America beverages, you've talked about CSD's softness, but categories like sports drinks and water improving. So do you think there is more of an impact from the weather just being pretty favorable in the summer? How much of the
componenttext: Just following up on North America beverages, you've talked about CSD's softness, but categories like sports drinks and water improving. So do you think there is more of an impact from the weather just being pretty favorable in the summer? How much of the improvement that you're seeing on some of these non-carb categories do you think is really sustainable if you look out over the next 12 months?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say because year was bad. The weather's been bad. We've had decent volume growth when the weather's been good. We haven't had decent volume growth, so I don't think there's a predicable number we can assign to the weather, Judy. The good news
componenttext: It's hard to say because year was bad. The weather's been bad. We've had decent volume growth when the weather's been good. We haven't had decent volume growth, so I don't think there's a predicable number we can assign to the weather, Judy. The good news is that even in Gatorade, which did exceedingly well this summer, the growth came not just from our core Gatorade, but also came from the launch of our new products, Prime and Recover. So that says to us that the core franchise is doing well. And if Prime and Recover did well, it's because the sports enthusiasts really believe in those products to enhance their performance. Similarly, a lot of the other innovations that we have like SoBe Life Water, I am not sure are just weather related. So let's wait and see how the fourth quarter and first quarter of next year evolve and then we should be able to talk more about the weather and its impact on the business. Hugh, did you want to add anything?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, just one further thought on that, Judy. Typically, of course, when the weather is hot, you see a nice jump in the Cold Channel business. I think the thing that makes us feel good about the Non-Core business right now is, we've also seen nice pickup i
componenttext: Yes, just one further thought on that, Judy. Typically, of course, when the weather is hot, you see a nice jump in the Cold Channel business. I think the thing that makes us feel good about the Non-Core business right now is, we've also seen nice pickup in the ambient channels as well, the large case pack channels. So that suggests that's more than just weather, but there really is good brand building effect and it's having an impact in the marketplace.

componenttext: Eric or Massimo, did you want to add anything?

componenttextpreview: I can just say two words on Gatorade to reinforce what you said. We're seeing a growing try-and-repeat level of our products as well some improving numbers on the Base business, Judy. So we feel good on the long-term sustainability of the Gatorade perform
componenttext: I can just say two words on Gatorade to reinforce what you said. We're seeing a growing try-and-repeat level of our products as well some improving numbers on the Base business, Judy. So we feel good on the long-term sustainability of the Gatorade performance. And the other thing, as you know, on Juices, Trop50 is growing double digit. We launched the new packaging. We have extended beyond orange into cranberry and apples. And all of these new products are really there for the long term. So we feel pretty good about it.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marc, this is Hugh. I really question the characterization of anything not delivering as we expected, to be perfectly honest with you. From our standpoint, we gave a range of 11% to 13%. We've consistently said 11% to 13%. And we're now staying within tha
componenttext: Marc, this is Hugh. I really question the characterization of anything not delivering as we expected, to be perfectly honest with you. From our standpoint, we gave a range of 11% to 13%. We've consistently said 11% to 13%. And we're now staying within that range of 11% to 13%. What we've really talked about here is much more geared towards making investments and good opportunities in the marketplace. Some of which are near-in in nature. Some of which are a little bit further out in nature, but all of which are geared towards building the business and all of which had good returns on them. So in terms of any expectation that we had, frankly, it's exactly in line with what we have been communicating, so no big change from our standpoint. The July reference is what's puzzling for me. In terms of where we expect revenue to go, obviously, we saw a good solid performance in the third quarter, and we're expecting to continue to see good solid revenue performance. SO we feel good about the operating performance in the business right now.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marc, let's just talk about some of the spending areas. Hugh talked about spending in China, accelerated spending in China, stepped-up levels. Look, when you spend in China and put in coolers, marketplace investments, you're not going to get the profitabi
componenttext: Marc, let's just talk about some of the spending areas. Hugh talked about spending in China, accelerated spending in China, stepped-up levels. Look, when you spend in China and put in coolers, marketplace investments, you're not going to get the profitability impact in the next 12 or 24 months. It takes a longer time because we are still in a massive investment mode in China. This has got years and years of growth. When we step up investments in India, again, you're not getting the returns right away. But it's a must-invest market because the demographics and the fact that per capita levels are so low gives you many years of growth. So we are making stepped-up investments in these countries because either we've got the permission to invest or we see an opportunity to go in with a new product or a marketplace investment at favorable terms today. So we're looking around the world and wherever we see the opportunity, we are ramping up the investments. But just remember the international markets is not like the United States where you get a return within the quarter. It does take two, three, four years before the top line starts ramping up in a meaningful way.

componenttext: No, what we've said is, we were between 11% and 13%, and we're now tightening to 11% to 12%. And the increment is geared towards investing in largely developing markets and in NAB brand building. so that's really where we are.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, Christine, I think if you look at the composition of growth in third quarter, what you would have seen is an increase in the performance of our water portfolio, largely driven by enhanced water. The non-carbs performed well and improved
componenttext: As I said earlier, Christine, I think if you look at the composition of growth in third quarter, what you would have seen is an increase in the performance of our water portfolio, largely driven by enhanced water. The non-carbs performed well and improved broadly. Certainly, Gatorade had a great quarter. As I mentioned earlier, tea, energy, ready-to-drink coffee all had a solid growth. The CSD category in total was soft in third quarter. And within our portfolio, I mentioned MAX was a big positive for us. The core Dew business performed well. And so at the end of the day, water and non-carbs performed extremely well. And the CSD category was soft and we kind of performed in line with the category.

componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So Trop50 is performing ahead of expectations as I said earlier. And as you know it's a higher margin product than the core TPP business. So every case of Trop50 is accretive to the overall algorithm. And across the portfolio, we are now in li
componenttext: Absolutely. So Trop50 is performing ahead of expectations as I said earlier. And as you know it's a higher margin product than the core TPP business. So every case of Trop50 is accretive to the overall algorithm. And across the portfolio, we are now in line with expectations, and we have some strong innovation plans for the Juice business for 2011.

componenttext: This is John. A slight improvement from Q2 to Q3. And the unit growth, we've said, low single-digit unit growth. Now that the 20% More Free is behind us, that should become the proxy for volume growth, which as you know, has been the historical volume growth in the company.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 07, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me just wrap up this call. And let me give you some headlines that you should takeaway. Macroeconomic environment, U.S. and Europe sluggish. The rest of the world improving to buoyant. Our category reflects the economic performance of the country.
componenttext: So let me just wrap up this call. And let me give you some headlines that you should takeaway. Macroeconomic environment, U.S. and Europe sluggish. The rest of the world improving to buoyant. Our category reflects the economic performance of the country. Our company performance is ahead of the categories and industry. Our operating approach, invest to transform our businesses, consistent with changing lifestyles in society; second, judiciously balancing the short term and the long term. And the overall sentiment in PepsiCo, prepared and confident. We are feeling good. Thank you.
